Paragraph.Text: is kept under surveillance by a person in possession of an active restricted area identity card that has been issued to them, in the case of an area the limits of which are defined for a specific purpose, such as construction or maintenance.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of the following persons:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: passengers who have been screened; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: inspectors.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that at least one escort is provided for every 10 persons who require escort.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that no more than 20 persons at a time are kept under surveillance by one person.
A person under escort must remain with the escort while the person is in a restricted area.
An escort must remain with the person under escort while the person is in a restricted area.
The person who appoints an escort must inform the escort of the requirement to remain with the person under escort while that person is in a restricted area.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a person under escort or surveillance at the aerodrome and any goods in the person’s possession or control are screened at a screening checkpoint before the person enters a sterile area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome is not required to place an escort or surveillance personnel in a conveyance that is in a restricted area at the aerodrome and is carrying persons who require escort or surveillance if the conveyance travels in a convoy with an escort conveyance that contains at least one person in possession of an active restricted area identity card that has been issued to them.

The operator of the aerodrome must ensure that, if a person who requires escort or surveillance disembarks from a conveyance in a restricted area at the aerodrome, the person is escorted or kept under surveillance in accordance with section 180.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that, at the aerodrome, at least one escort conveyance is provided for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every three conveyances requiring escort to or from an air terminal building apron area for a purpose other than snow removal operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every six conveyances requiring escort to or from an air terminal building apron area for snow removal operations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every six conveyances requiring escort to or from a restricted area other than an air terminal building apron area.

Section.Text: Nothing in this Division requires an inspector acting in the course of their employment to be in possession of a restricted area identity card or any other document issued or approved by the operator of an aerodrome as authorization for the inspector to enter or remain in a restricted area.

The credentials issued by the Minister to an inspector do not constitute a restricted area identity card even if the credentials are compatible with the identity verification system or with an access control system established by the operator of an aerodrome.
Nothing in this Division prohibits an inspector from escorting a person who is in a restricted area and is not in possession of a restricted area identity card if the inspector

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is acting in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not escort more than 10 persons at one time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: remains with the person while the person is in the restricted area;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensures that the person remains with the inspector while the person is in the restricted area; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensures that the person and any goods in their possession or control are screened at a screening checkpoint before the person enters a sterile area.

Subsection.Text: Nothing in this Division prohibits an inspector from escorting a person who is in a conveyance in a restricted area and is not in possession of a restricted area identity card if the inspector

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is acting in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not escort more than 10 persons at one time; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is either in the conveyance or in an escort conveyance that is travelling in a convoy with the conveyance.

Subsection.Text: If a person under escort disembarks from a conveyance in a restricted area, the inspector must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: remain with the person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person remains with the inspector.

Subsection.Text: If a person under escort is travelling to or from an air terminal building apron area, the Minister must ensure that at least one escort conveyance is provided for every three conveyances requiring escort in a convoy and that at least one inspector is in each escort conveyance.

If a person under escort is travelling to or from a restricted area other than an air terminal building apron area, the Minister must ensure that at least one escort conveyance is provided for every six conveyances requiring escort in a convoy and that at least one inspector is in each escort conveyance.

Section.Text: This Division sets out the regulatory framework for promoting a comprehensive, coordinated and integrated approach to airport security. The processes required under this Division are intended to facilitate the establishment and implementation of effective airport security programs that reflect the circumstances of each aerodrome.
For greater certainty, any reference to a process in this Division includes the procedures, if any, that are necessary to implement that process.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must establish and implement an airport security program.
As part of its airport security program, the operator of an aerodrome must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: define and document the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities assigned to each of the operator’s employee groups and contractor groups;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: communicate the information referred to in paragraph (a) to the employees and contractors in those groups;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a security policy statement that establishes an overall commitment and direction for aerodrome security and sets out the operator’s security objectives;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: communicate the security policy statement in an accessible manner to all persons who are employed at the aerodrome or who require access to the aerodrome in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish and implement a process for responding to aerodrome-related security incidents and breaches in a coordinated manner that is intended to minimize their impact;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: establish and implement a security awareness program that promotes a culture of security vigilance and awareness among the following persons:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: persons who are employed at the aerodrome,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: crew members who are based at the aerodrome, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: persons, other than crew members, who require access to the aerodrome in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: assess risk information and disseminate it within the operator’s organization for the purpose of informed decision-making about aviation security;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: establish and implement a process for receiving, retaining, disclosing and disposing of sensitive information respecting aviation security in order to protect the information from unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: identify sensitive information respecting aviation security and receive, retain, disclose and dispose of sensitive information respecting aviation security in a manner that protects the information from unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: disclose sensitive information respecting aviation security to the following persons if they have been assigned aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities and require the information to carry out those roles and responsibilities:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: persons who are employed at the aerodrome, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: persons who require access to the aerodrome in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: have a current scale map of the aerodrome that identifies all restricted areas, security barriers and restricted area access points; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: document how the operator achieves compliance with the aviation security provisions of the Act and the regulatory requirements that apply to the operator.

Subsection.Text: The following also form part of the airport security program:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the security official referred to in section 112;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aerodrome security personnel training referred to in sections 115 and 116;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the security committee or other working group or forum referred to in section 195;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the multi-agency advisory committee referred to in section 196;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the airport security risk assessment referred to in section 197;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the strategic airport security plan referred to in section 202;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency plan referred to in section 206; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the security exercises referred to in sections 207 and 208.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: keep documentation related to its airport security risk assessment and any review of it for at least five years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep documentation related to its strategic airport security plan and any amendment to it for at least five years; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: keep all other documentation related to its airport security program for at least two years.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must make the documentation available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must amend its airport security program if the operator identifies, at the aerodrome, an aviation security risk that is not addressed by the program.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must have a security committee or other working group or forum that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: advises the operator on the development of controls and processes that are necessary at the aerodrome in order to comply with the aviation security provisions of the Act and the regulatory requirements that apply to the operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: helps coordinate the implementation of the controls and processes that are necessary at the aerodrome in order to comply with the aviation security provisions of the Act and the regulatory requirements that apply to the operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: promotes the sharing of information respecting the airport security program.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must manage the security committee or other working group or forum in accordance with written terms of reference that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify its membership; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: define the roles and responsibilities of each member.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must keep records of the activities and decisions of the security committee or other working group or forum.
The operator of an aerodrome must have a multi-agency advisory committee.
The operator of the aerodrome must invite at least the following persons and organizations to be members of the multi-agency advisory committee:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the police service with jurisdiction at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Royal Canadian Mounted Police;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the Canadian Security Intelligence Service; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the Canada Border Services Agency.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must manage the multi-agency advisory committee in accordance with written terms of reference.
The objectives of the multi-agency advisory committee are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to advise the operator of the aerodrome on its airport security risk assessment and its strategic airport security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to promote the sharing of sensitive information respecting aviation security at the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must keep records of the activities and decisions of the multi-agency advisory committee.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must have an airport security risk assessment that identifies, assesses and prioritizes aviation security risks and that includes the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a threat assessment that evaluates the probability that aviation security incidents will occur at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a criticality assessment that prioritizes the areas, assets, infrastructure and operations at or associated with the aerodrome that most require protection from acts and attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a vulnerability assessment that considers the extent to which the areas, assets, infrastructure and operations at or associated with the aerodrome are susceptible to loss or damage and that evaluates this susceptibility in the context of the threat assessment; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an impact assessment that, at a minimum, measures the consequences of an aviation security incident or potential aviation security incident in terms of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a decrease in public safety and security,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: financial and economic loss, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a loss of public confidence.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must submit its airport security risk assessment to the Minister for approval, and must submit a new airport security risk assessment to the Minister within five years after the date of the most recent approval.
The operator of an aerodrome must consult its multi-agency advisory committee when the operator is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preparing its airport security risk assessment for submission to the Minister for approval; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conducting a review of its airport security risk assessment.

Section.MarginalNote: Airport security risk assessment — annual review

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must conduct a review of its airport security risk assessment at least once a year.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Airport security risk assessment — other reviews
Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must also conduct a review of its airport security risk assessment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a special event that is scheduled to take place at the aerodrome could affect aerodrome security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator is planning a change to the physical layout or operation of the aerodrome that could affect aviation security at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an environmental or operational change at the aerodrome could affect aerodrome security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a change in regulatory requirements could affect aerodrome security;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operator identifies, at the aerodrome, a vulnerability that is not addressed in the assessment, or the Minister identifies such a vulnerability to the operator; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs the operator that there is a change in the threat environment that could result in a new or unaddressed medium to high risk.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, a review conducted under subsection (2) counts as a review required under subsection (1).
When the operator of the aerodrome conducts a review of its airport security risk assessment, the operator must document

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any decision to amend or to not amend the assessment or the operator’s risk-management strategy;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for that decision; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the factors that were taken into consideration in making that decision.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must notify the Minister if, as a result of a review of its airport security risk assessment, the operator amends the assessment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to include a new medium to high risk; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to raise or lower the level of a risk within the medium to high range.

Section.Text: The Minister must approve an airport security risk assessment submitted by the operator of an aerodrome if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the assessment meets the requirements of section 197;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the assessment has been reviewed by an executive within the operator’s organization who is responsible for security;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has considered risk information provided by its multi-agency advisory committee;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has considered all available and relevant information; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has not overlooked an aviation security risk that could affect the operation of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must establish a strategic airport security plan that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: summarizes the operator’s strategy to prepare for, detect, prevent, respond to and recover from acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: includes a risk-management strategy that addresses the medium to high aviation security risks identified and prioritized in the operator’s airport security risk assessment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sets out a menu of additional safeguards that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: intended to mitigate heightened risk conditions in a graduated manner, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: consistent with the operator’s legal powers and obligations.

Subsection.Text: The menu of additional safeguards must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: describe, by activity type and location, the safeguards in place at the aerodrome in respect of AVSEC level 1 operating conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: allow the rapid selection of additional safeguards by activity type or location; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: indicate the persons and organizations responsible for implementing each additional safeguard.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraphs (2)(a) and (b), the activity types must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: access controls;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: monitoring and patrolling;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: communications; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: other operational controls.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraphs (2)(a) and (b), the locations must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: public areas of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: areas of the aerodrome that are not public areas but are not restricted areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: restricted areas.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must consult its multi-agency advisory committee when the operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establishes its strategic airport security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: amends its strategic airport security plan under subsection 205.2(1).

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must submit its strategic airport security plan to the Minister for approval.
The operator of an aerodrome must, as soon as its strategic airport security plan is approved, implement its risk-management strategy.
The Minister must approve a strategic airport security plan submitted by the operator of an aerodrome if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plan meets the requirements of section 202;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the plan has been reviewed by an executive within the operator’s organization who is responsible for security;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the plan is likely to enable the operator to prepare for, detect, prevent, respond to and recover from acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the risk-management strategy is in proportion to the risks it addresses;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has considered the advice of its multi-agency advisory committee;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has not overlooked an aviation security risk that could affect the operation of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the additional safeguards can be implemented rapidly and consistently;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the additional safeguards are consistent with existing rights and freedoms; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the plan can be implemented without compromising aviation security.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may amend its strategic airport security plan at any time, but must do so if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plan does not reflect the operator’s most recent airport security risk assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs the operator that there is a change in the threat environment that could result in a new or unaddressed medium to high risk;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs the operator that there is a change in the threat environment that requires the addition or deletion of additional safeguards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs the operator that its risk-management strategy is not in proportion to a medium to high risk set out in the operator’s airport security risk assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operator identifies a deficiency in the plan; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a change is made in the aviation security provisions of the Act or in regulatory requirements and the change affects the additional safeguards.

Subsection.Text: If the operator of the aerodrome amends its strategic airport security plan, the operator must document

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the amendment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the factors that were taken into consideration in making that amendment.

Subsection.Text: If the operator of the aerodrome amends its strategic airport security plan, the operator must, as soon as possible, submit the amendment to the Minister for approval.
The Minister must approve an amendment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an amendment to the summary required under paragraph 202(1)(a), the conditions set out in paragraphs 205.1(a) to (c) have been met;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an amendment to the risk-management strategy required under paragraph 202(1)(b), the conditions set out in paragraphs 205.1(a) to (f) and (i) have been met; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an amendment to the menu of additional safeguards required under paragraph 202(1)(c), the conditions set out in paragraphs 205.1(a), (b) and (f) to (i) have been met.

Subsection.Text: If the operator of the aerodrome amends its risk-management strategy, the operator must implement the amended version of the strategy once it is approved by the Minister.
The operator of an aerodrome must establish an emergency plan that sets out the response procedures to be followed at the aerodrome for coordinated responses to the following emergencies:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: bomb threats;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hijackings of aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: other acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Subsection.Text: The response procedures must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in detail the actions to be taken by the employees and contractors of the operator of the aerodrome and identify the responsibilities of all other persons or organizations involved, including, as applicable, the police, emergency response providers, air carriers, emergency coordination centre personnel and control tower or flight service station personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include detailed procedures for the evacuation of air terminal buildings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include detailed procedures for the search of air terminal buildings;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include detailed procedures for the handling and disposal of a suspected bomb; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: include detailed procedures for the detention on the ground of any aircraft involved in a bomb threat or hijacking.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must, at least once every two years, carry out an operations-based security exercise that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tests the effectiveness of the operator’s emergency plan in response to an act of unlawful interference with civil aviation and involves the persons and organizations referred to in the plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tests the effectiveness of additional safeguards that the operator chooses from its menu of additional safeguards.

Subsection.Text: If, in response to an aviation security incident, the Minister raises the AVSEC level for an aerodrome or any part of an aerodrome, the implementation of additional safeguards by the operator of the aerodrome counts as an operations-based security exercise for the purposes of subsection (1).
The operator of an aerodrome must, at least once a year, carry out a discussion-based security exercise that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tests the effectiveness of the operator’s emergency plan in response to an act of unlawful interference with civil aviation and involves the persons and organizations referred to in the plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tests the effectiveness of additional safeguards that the operator chooses from its menu of additional safeguards.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), the operator of an aerodrome is not required to carry out a discussion-based security exercise in any year in which it carries out an operations-based security exercise.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must give the Minister 60 days’ notice of any security exercise that the operator plans to carry out.

Subsection.Text: Each time additional safeguards are implemented at an aerodrome in order to mitigate heightened risk conditions related to aviation security, the operator of the aerodrome must create a record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the additional safeguards that were implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of those additional safeguards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any actions that are planned in order to address deficiencies identified during the implementation of those additional safeguards.

Subsection.Text: Each time an emergency referred to in subsection 206(1) occurs at an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must create a record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of the operator’s emergency plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any actions that are planned in order to address deficiencies identified during the emergency.

Subsection.Text: Each time a security exercise is carried out at an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must create a record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an outline of the exercise scenario;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of the exercise; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any actions that are planned in order to address deficiencies identified during the exercise.

Section.Text: Subject to section 212, the operator of an aerodrome must immediately take corrective actions to address a vulnerability that contributes to a heightened aviation security risk at the aerodrome and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is identified to the operator by the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is identified by the operator.

Section.Text: If a corrective action to be taken by the operator of an aerodrome under section 211 involves a phased approach, the operator must include in its airport security program a corrective action plan that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the vulnerability to be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rationale for the phased approach; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a timetable setting out when each phase of the corrective action plan will be completed.

Section.Text: A person other than the Minister must not disclose security-sensitive information that is created or used under this Division unless the disclosure is required by law or is necessary to comply or facilitate compliance with the aviation security provisions of the Act, regulatory requirements or the requirements of an emergency direction.
This Division sets out the role of a primary security line partner in supporting the establishment and implementation of an effective airport security program by the operator of an aerodrome.
A security official of a primary security line partner at an aerodrome is an individual who is responsible for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating and overseeing compliance with the regulatory requirements that apply to the partner under this Part; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acting as the principal contact between the partner, the operator of the aerodrome and the Minister with respect to security matters, including compliance with the regulatory requirements that apply to the partner under this Part.

Section.MarginalNote: One security official at all times

Subsection.Text: A primary security line partner at an aerodrome must have, at all times, at least one security official or acting security official.
The primary security line partner must provide the operator of the aerodrome and the Minister with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each security official and acting security official; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 24-hour contact information for those officials.

Section.Text: At each aerodrome where a primary security line partner carries out operations, the partner must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: define and document the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities assigned to each of the partner’s employee groups and contractor groups that require access to restricted areas at the aerodrome in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: communicate the information referred to in paragraph (a) to the employees and contractors in those groups and document how that information is communicated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establish, implement and document a security awareness program that promotes a culture of security vigilance and awareness among its employees and contractors if the security awareness program of the operator of the aerodrome does not cover matters that are unique to the partner’s operations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: document the measures, procedures and processes that the partner has in place at the aerodrome to protect the security of restricted areas and to prevent breaches of the primary security line;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: create a document that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: describes each area on the aerodrome’s primary security line that is occupied by the partner,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates the location of each restricted area access point in those areas, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: describes those restricted area access points;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: establish, implement and document a process for receiving, retaining, disclosing and disposing of sensitive information respecting aerodrome security in order to protect the information from unauthorized access; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: identify sensitive information respecting aviation security and receive, retain, disclose and dispose of sensitive information respecting aerodrome security in a manner that protects the information from unauthorized access.

Section.MarginalNote: Provision of information to operator of aerodrome

Subsection.Text: At each aerodrome where a primary security line partner carries out operations, the partner must provide the operator of the aerodrome with the information that is documented or created under this Division on reasonable notice given by the operator.
The primary security line partner must provide the Minister with the same information on reasonable notice given by the Minister.
Subject to section 235, a primary security line partner must immediately take corrective actions to address a vulnerability that contributes to an aerodrome-related security risk and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is identified to the partner by the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is identified to the partner by the operator of the aerodrome where the partner carries out operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is identified by the partner.

Subsection.Text: If a primary security line partner takes corrective actions at an aerodrome, the primary security line partner must immediately notify the operator of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: If a corrective action to be taken by a primary security line partner under section 234 involves a phased approach, the primary security line partner must provide the Minister and the operator of the aerodrome with a corrective action plan that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the vulnerability to be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rationale for the phased approach; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a timetable setting out when each phase of the corrective action plan will be completed.

Section.Text: A person other than the Minister must not disclose security-sensitive information that is created or used under this Division unless the disclosure is required by law or is necessary to comply or facilitate compliance with the aviation security provisions of the Act, regulatory requirements or the requirements of an emergency direction.
This Division sets out requirements respecting aerodrome operations that are not dealt with in any other Division of this Part.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must notify the Minister of all plans to begin new construction or to make a change to the physical security of the aerodrome, if the construction or change relates to regulatory requirements respecting passengers, aircraft, baggage, cargo or mail.
The notice must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: state the date on which the construction will begin or the change will be made; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out a description of the construction or change and the safeguards that will be implemented to maintain security in the areas of the aerodrome that will be affected by the construction activities.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome that has a United States preclearance area must ensure the continuous presence of at least one armed police officer at the preclearance area during the hours that the area is in operation.

The operator of the aerodrome must ensure that the armed police officer makes regular patrols within the preclearance area and responds rapidly and in person to any emergency calls from, or alarms activated by, United States preclearance personnel.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the basic regulatory framework for security at aerodromes listed in Schedule 2.
This Part applies in respect of aerodromes listed in Schedule 2.
This Division completes and supplements the regulatory framework set out in Part 3.

Heading.TitleText: Authorization for Carriage of or Access to Explosive Substances and Incendiary Devices

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to carry or have access to an explosive substance or an incendiary device at the aerodrome if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive substance or incendiary device is to be used at the aerodrome

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for excavation, demolition or construction work,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in fireworks displays,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: by persons operating explosives detection equipment or handling explosives detection dogs,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: by a police service, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: by military personnel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has reasonable grounds to believe that the safety of the aerodrome and the safety of persons and aircraft at the aerodrome will not be jeopardized by the presence of the explosive substance or incendiary device.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not permit goods listed or described in the general list of prohibited items or, as applicable, the specific list of prohibited items to be made available to persons in a sterile area.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of liquids, aerosols and gels that are made available to persons in accordance with a security measure.

Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of rounded, dull-blade knives and plastic knives that are made available to the customers of a concessionaire with the permission of the operator of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: This Division sets out the regulatory framework for dealing with threats and incidents at an aerodrome.

The operator of an aerodrome who is made aware of a threat against an aviation facility, or a part of the aerodrome, that is under the operator’s control must immediately determine whether there is a specific threat that jeopardizes the security of the facility or that part of the aerodrome.

Section.MarginalNote: Area under control of other person
Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who is made aware of a threat against an aviation facility, or a part of the aerodrome, that is under the control of a person carrying on any activity at the aerodrome, other than the operator, must immediately

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify the person of the nature of the threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determine whether there is a specific threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who determines that there is a specific threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome must immediately take all of the measures necessary to ensure the safety of the aerodrome and persons at the aerodrome, including informing the appropriate police service of the nature of the threat.
A person, other than a screening authority, who is carrying on any activity at an aerodrome and who is made aware of a threat against the aerodrome must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately notify the operator of the aerodrome of the nature of the threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assist the operator of the aerodrome in determining whether there is a specific threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: If it is determined under paragraph 15(b), 254(b) or 256(b) that there is a specific threat that jeopardizes the security of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately take all of the measures necessary to ensure the safety of the aerodrome and persons at the aerodrome, including informing the appropriate police service of the nature of the threat.
The operator of an aerodrome must immediately notify the Minister when any of the following incidents occur:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the discovery, at the aerodrome, of a weapon, explosive substance or incendiary device that is not permitted under subsection 78(2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an explosion at the aerodrome, unless the explosion is known to be the result of an accident, excavation, demolition or construction work, or the use of fireworks displays;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a specific threat against the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an aviation security incident that involves a peace officer anywhere at the aerodrome other than areas under an air carrier’s control.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must provide the Minister with written notice of any new commercial air service that is to begin at an air terminal building.
This Division sets out requirements respecting the implementation of additional safeguards in the event of heightened risk conditions.
If the AVSEC level is raised or maintained above level 1 for an aerodrome or any part of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately take the following actions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine which additional safeguards are likely to mitigate the heightened risk condition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify any persons or organizations that have aviation security roles and responsibilities at the aerodrome and are affected by the heightened risk condition;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: implement or continue to implement the additional safeguards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the Minister of the additional safeguards that are being or will be implemented.

Section.Text: When the AVSEC level is lowered for an aerodrome or any part of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately notify the persons and organizations that were notified under paragraph 261(b).
For greater certainty, nothing in these Regulations authorizes the operator of an aerodrome to implement additional safeguards that are inconsistent with the operator’s legal powers and obligations.
This Division sets out requirements respecting aerodrome security personnel and other persons who are assigned aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities at an aerodrome.
A security official of an aerodrome is an individual who is responsible for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating and overseeing security controls and procedures at the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acting as the principal contact between the operator of the aerodrome and the Minister with respect to security matters, including the airport security program.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must have, at all times, at least one security official or acting security official.
The operator of the aerodrome must provide the Minister with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each security official and acting security official; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 24-hour contact information for those officials.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a member of the aerodrome security personnel does not carry out an aerodrome-related security role or responsibility at the aerodrome unless the member has received initial training in relation to that role or responsibility.

Initial training for aerodrome security personnel must include instruction and evaluation in relation to the topics set out below that are relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: international instruments respecting aviation security, the aviation security provisions of the Act and regulatory requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the security controls and procedures at the aerodrome where the personnel are employed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: systems and equipment at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an overview of threats to aviation security and acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of goods that are listed or described in TP 14628 or that pose an immediate threat to aviation security; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken by the personnel in response to a threat to aviation security or an act or attempted act of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Subsection.Text: Aerodrome security personnel who are employed at the aerodrome on the day on which this section comes into force are exempted from initial training in relation to any topic for which they have already received training.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that aerodrome security personnel receive follow-up training when any of the following circumstances arise:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a change is made in the aviation security provisions of the Act or in regulatory requirements and the change is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a change is made in the security controls and procedures at the aerodrome where the personnel are employed and the change is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a new or modified action is to be taken by the personnel in response to a threat to aviation security or an act or attempted act of unlawful interference with civil aviation; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a significant risk or an emerging trend in aviation security is identified to the operator by the Minister and the risk or trend is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a member of the aerodrome security personnel receives follow-up training when the Minister or the operator identifies a shortcoming in the member’s performance when the member is carrying out security controls or following security procedures at the aerodrome.
Follow-up training must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a review of any initial-training element related to the circumstance set out in subsection (1) or (2) that gave rise to the follow-up training; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: instruction and evaluation in relation to that circumstance.

Section.Text: If, at an aerodrome, the initial or follow-up training of aerodrome security personnel includes on-the-job training, the operator of the aerodrome must ensure that the on-the-job training is provided by a person who has received that same training or has significant experience working as a member of the aerodrome security personnel at an aerodrome listed in Schedule 1 or 2.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that, for each individual who receives training in accordance with section 271 or 272, there is a training record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the individual’s employee group or contractor group, if applicable, and a description of the individual’s aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of all the training that the individual has received in accordance with section 271 or 272; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: evaluation results for all the training that the individual has received in accordance with section 271 or 272.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must keep the training record for at least two years.
The operator of the aerodrome must make the training record available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: This Division sets out requirements respecting the facilitation of screening operations at an aerodrome.
The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for passenger screening checkpoints and must make at least one facility available for the private screening of passengers.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must post a notice at each passenger screening checkpoint stating that it is an offence for a person at the aerodrome to falsely declare

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft, or that such an item is contained in goods in the person’s possession or control or in goods that the person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that another person who is at an aerodrome or on board an aircraft is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft, or that such an item is contained in goods in the other person’s possession or control or in goods that the other person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation.

Subsection.Text: The notice must be clearly visible and be in at least both official languages.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for non-passenger screening checkpoints at restricted area access points and at locations inside restricted areas.

The operator of an aerodrome must, in accordance with a security measure, ensure that non-passengers enter a restricted area at the aerodrome only through a restricted area access point where screening is carried out.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that non-passengers who access sterile areas are notified of any restrictions on the possession of liquids, aerosols or gels in sterile areas.
The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for the screening of checked baggage and baggage intended to be checked baggage.

If the operator of an aerodrome is responsible for a baggage handling system, the operator must not make any change to the system that may affect screening operations unless the change is agreed to by CATSA.
This Division sets out the regulatory framework for the protection of security-sensitive areas of aerodromes.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must post signs on the outside of each restricted area access point and each security barrier. Each sign must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in at least both official languages;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the restricted area as a restricted area; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state that access to the area is restricted to authorized persons.

Subsection.Text: The signs posted on a security barrier must be no more than 150 m apart.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that each restricted area access point that allows access from a non-restricted area to a restricted area has an access control system consisting of one or more of the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: surveillance by a person authorized by the operator of the aerodrome to control access to the restricted area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manual locking equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: automated access control equipment.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that each restricted area access point that is located between an air terminal building and a passenger loading bridge has a door that can be locked.
A person must not enter a restricted area at an aerodrome except through a restricted area access point.
The operator of an aerodrome must take measures to prevent unauthorized access to a baggage handling system that is in a restricted area.

Heading.TitleText: Doors, Gates, Emergency Exits and Other Devices

Section.MarginalNote: Duty to close and lock — operators

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must close and lock any door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has control of and responsibility for the door, gate or other device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door, gate or other device allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must institute a system, on or near an emergency exit, that prevents access by unauthorized persons to a restricted area, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has control of and responsibility for the emergency exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency exit allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Section.MarginalNote: Duty to close and lock — partners and lessees

Subsection.Text: A primary security line partner, or a lessee other than a primary security line partner, at an aerodrome must close and lock any door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the partner or lessee has control of and responsibility for the door, gate or other device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door, gate or other device allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Subsection.Text: A primary security line partner who occupies an area on an aerodrome’s primary security line must institute a system, on or near an emergency exit, that prevents access by unauthorized persons to a restricted area, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the partner has control of and responsibility for the emergency exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency exit allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Section.Text: Any person at an aerodrome who has temporary use or control of a door, gate or other device that allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area must prevent access to or from the restricted area by unauthorized persons.
Unless an authorized person is controlling access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area at an aerodrome, a person who enters or leaves the restricted area must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lock the door, gate or other device that allows access to or from the restricted area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent access to or from the restricted area by unauthorized persons while the door, gate or other device is open or unlocked.

Section.Text: A person at an aerodrome must not prevent a door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, that allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area from being locked.
A person at an aerodrome must not open any door that is designated as an emergency exit and that is also a restricted area access point unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is authorized by the operator of the aerodrome to open it; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an emergency.

Subsection.Text: If a person has been given notice, orally, in writing or by a sign, that access to a part of an aerodrome is prohibited or is limited to authorized persons, the person must not enter or remain in that part of the aerodrome without authorization.
The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to enter or remain in a restricted area if the requirements of Divisions 6 to 8 are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Non-public areas other than restricted areas
Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to enter or remain in a part of the aerodrome that is not a public area but is not a restricted area if the safety of the aerodrome, persons at the aerodrome and aircraft is not jeopardized.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Non-public areas other than restricted areas
Subsection.Text: A lessee at an aerodrome who has the use of, or is responsible for, a part of the aerodrome that is not a public area but is not a restricted area may authorize a person to enter or remain in that part of the aerodrome if the safety of the aerodrome, persons at the aerodrome and aircraft is not jeopardized.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must allow an inspector to enter or remain in a restricted area if the inspector is acting in the course of their employment and presents their credentials.
This Division sets out provisions respecting documents of entitlement. Requirements respecting the issue and use of restricted area identity card are set out in Division 8.

Subsection.Text: Only the following documents are documents of entitlement at an aerodrome:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a restricted area identity card;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a temporary pass issued by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a boarding pass, a ticket, or any other document accepted by an air carrier that confirms the status of the person to whom it was issued as a passenger on a flight and that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger escort form that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a courtesy-lounge or conference-room pass that is issued by an air carrier and that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a document that is issued or approved by the operator of the aerodrome in accordance with a security measure.

Subsection.Text: A pilot’s licence issued under the Canadian Aviation Regulations is a document of entitlement for a restricted area that is used by general aviation, if the holder of the licence also holds a valid medical certificate of a category that is appropriate for that licence and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is acting in the course of their employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: requires access to an aircraft that they own or operate.

Section.Text: This Division sets out enhanced access control requirements, including requirements respecting the identity verification system referred to in section 56.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome is authorized to disclose to the Minister or CATSA any information that is necessary for the proper operation of the identity verification system.

Despite subsection (1), the operator of an aerodrome must not disclose to CATSA the identity of an applicant for a restricted area identity card or the identity of a person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued unless the operator grants CATSA access to its databases to maintain or repair the identity verification system and CATSA’s access to the person’s identity is incidental to the maintenance or repairs.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Displayed on a Restricted Area Identity Card

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that the following information is displayed on each restricted area identity card that it issues:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the full name of the person to whom the card is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s height;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph depicting a frontal view of the person’s face;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the expiry date of the card;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the aerodrome where the card is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person’s employer, if the person has a single employer;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the terms “multi-employer” and “employeur multiple”, if the person has more than one employer;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s occupation, if the person has a single occupation; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the terms “multi-occupation” and “emplois multiples”, if the person has more than one occupation.

Subsection.Text: A restricted area identity card expires no later than five years after the day on which it is issued or on the day on which the security clearance of the person to whom the card is issued expires, whichever is earlier.

Despite subsection (2), a restricted area identity card that is issued to a person who requires access to restricted areas at more than one aerodrome, but who is not a crew member, expires no later than one year after the day on which it is issued or on the day on which the person’s security clearance expires, whichever is earlier.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that all information that is displayed on a restricted area identity card is in both official languages.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of Restricted Area Identity Cards

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not issue a restricted area identity card to a person unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: applies in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is sponsored in writing by their employer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a security clearance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: consents in writing to the collection, use, retention, disclosure and destruction of information for the purposes of this Division; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: confirms that the information displayed on the card is correct.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not issue a restricted area identity card to a person unless the card has been activated.

Section.Text: A person must not provide false information for the purpose of obtaining a restricted area identity card.
An employer must not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sponsor an employee who does not require ongoing access to restricted areas in the course of their employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly sponsor an employee for more than one restricted area identity card at a time.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not issue more than one restricted area identity card at a time to a person.
Before replacing a lost, stolen or non-functional restricted area identity card, the operator of an aerodrome must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person applying for the replacement card is the person to whom the lost, stolen or non-functional card has been issued; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person still has a security clearance.

Section.Text: Before collecting information from an applicant under this Division, the operator of an aerodrome must bring to the applicant’s attention the purposes for which the information is collected and the manner in which the information will be used, retained, disclosed and destroyed.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of creating a restricted area identity card for an applicant, the operator of an aerodrome must collect the following information from the applicant:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s height;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph depicting a frontal view of the applicant’s face;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s fingerprint images and iris images;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the applicant’s employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s occupation.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must, immediately after issuing the restricted area identity card, destroy all fingerprint images and iris images that the operator collected from the applicant and any biometric template created from those images that is not stored on the card.

Section.Text: For the purpose of allowing CATSA to monitor the quality of biometric templates and determining if a restricted area identity card is already active in respect of an applicant, the operator of an aerodrome must, before issuing the card, disclose to CATSA any biometric templates created from the fingerprint images and iris images collected from the applicant.

The operator of an aerodrome must take appropriate measures to protect information that is collected, used, retained or disclosed in accordance with this Division from loss or theft and from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, duplication or alteration.

Heading.TitleText: Deactivation of Restricted Area Identity Cards

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who has issued a restricted area identity card must immediately ask CATSA to deactivate the card if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the card expires;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person to whom the card has been issued or their employer informs the operator that the card is lost, stolen or no longer functional; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person to whom the card has been issued fails, on demand, to present or surrender the card to a screening officer.

Subsection.Text: If the operator of an aerodrome asks CATSA to deactivate a restricted area identity card, the operator must inform CATSA of the reason for the request.
The operator of an aerodrome must not ask CATSA to deactivate a restricted area identity card for a reason other than a reason set out in subsection (1).
The operator of an aerodrome must notify the Minister if the operator asks CATSA to deactivate a restricted area identity card.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who has issued a restricted area identity card must notify the Minister immediately if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who has a single employer, the person to whom the card has been issued ceases to be employed or no longer requires ongoing access to restricted areas in the course of their employment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who has more than one employer, the person to whom the card has been issued ceases to be employed by all of their employers or no longer requires ongoing access to restricted areas in the course of their employment.

Section.Text: The employer of a person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued must immediately notify the operator of an aerodrome who issued the card if the person ceases to be an employee or no longer requires ongoing access to restricted areas in the course of their employment.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who has issued a restricted area identity card must take reasonable steps to retrieve the card if it has been deactivated and must notify CATSA if the card is not retrieved.

If a restricted area identity card has been deactivated, the person to whom the card has been issued must immediately return it to the operator of an aerodrome who issued it unless the card was surrendered in accordance with this Division or was lost or stolen.

Heading.TitleText: Keys, Combination Codes and Personal Identification Codes

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not issue a key or assign a combination code or personal identification code to a person for a restricted area unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is a person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued and the card is active; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is in possession of a document that is issued or approved by the operator of the aerodrome in accordance with a security measure as authorization for the person to enter or remain in the restricted area.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may add a key to a restricted area identity card only if it is possible to cancel or remove the key without damaging or altering any other elements of the card.

The operator of an aerodrome must not add to or modify a restricted area identity card in any way that might allow the disclosure to CATSA of information about the person to whom the card has been issued.

The operator of an aerodrome must cancel, withdraw or retrieve a key that has been issued to a person who has been issued a restricted area identity card, or a combination code or personal identification code that has been assigned to that person, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s restricted area identity card has been deactivated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person no longer requires ongoing access to the restricted area in the course of their employment.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome and any person designated by the operator to issue restricted area identity cards or keys or to assign combination codes or personal identification codes must keep updated records at the aerodrome respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards and keys that have been issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the persons to whom restricted area identity cards or keys have been issued;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the persons to whom combination codes or personal identification codes have been assigned;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: blank restricted area identity cards in the operator’s possession;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards that have been deactivated;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: keys, combination codes or personal identification codes that have been cancelled, withdrawn or retrieved;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: deactivated restricted area identity cards that have not been retrieved by the operator;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards that have been reported as lost or stolen;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: steps taken to retrieve deactivated restricted area identity cards; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: compliance with section 307.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a record respecting a restricted area identity card that has been deactivated must be retained for at least one year from the day on which the card was deactivated.
A record respecting a restricted area identity card that has been reported as lost or stolen must be retained for at least one year from the card’s expiry date.
The operator of the aerodrome must provide the Minister with the records on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must implement and maintain a restricted area access control process that uses the identity verification system.

Heading.TitleText: Control of Access to Restricted Areas

Section.Text: A person must not enter or remain in a restricted area unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is in possession of a document of entitlement, other than a restricted area identity card, for the restricted area.

Section.MarginalNote: Restricted area identity cards — conditions of use

Subsection.Text: A person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued must not enter or remain in a restricted area unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are acting in the course of their employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the card is in their possession;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the card is active; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: as applicable, they are in possession of a key that has been issued to them for the restricted area, or a combination code or personal identification code that has been assigned to them for the restricted area.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(d) does not apply to crew members.

Section.MarginalNote: Display of restricted area identity cards

Subsection.Text: A person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued must not enter or remain in a restricted area unless they visibly display the card on their outer clothing at all times.
A person to whom a temporary pass has been issued must not enter or remain in a restricted area unless they visibly display the pass on their outer clothing at all times.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a person is not allowed to enter or remain in a restricted area at the aerodrome unless the person is in possession of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an active restricted area identity card that has been issued to the person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a document of entitlement, other than a restricted area identity card, for the restricted area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must develop and maintain a business continuity plan that, at a minimum, sets out how the operator will re-establish normal operations and comply with section 324 in the event that the operator is unable to use its restricted area access control process to comply with that section.

The operator of the aerodrome must immediately implement its business continuity plan and notify the Minister and CATSA if the operator discovers that it is unable to use its restricted area access control process to comply with section 324.

The operator of the aerodrome must immediately notify the Minister if the operator discovers that it will be unable, for more than 24 hours, to use its restricted area access control process to comply with section 324.
The operator of the aerodrome must make its business continuity plan available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must regularly back up any database that the operator uses as part of the identity verification system.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Restricted Area Identity Cards, Keys, Combination Codes and Personal Identification Codes

Subsection.Text: A person must not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lend or give a restricted area identity card or a key that has been issued to them to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use a restricted area identity card or a key that has been issued to them to allow access to a restricted area at an aerodrome to another person without authorization from the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: intentionally alter or otherwise modify a restricted area identity card or a key unless they are the operator of an aerodrome or a person designated by the operator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: use a restricted area identity card or a key that has been issued to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have in their possession, without reasonable excuse, a restricted area identity card or a key that has been issued to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: use a counterfeit restricted area identity card or a counterfeit key; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: make a copy of a restricted area identity card or a key.

Subsection.Text: A person, other than the operator of an aerodrome or a person designated by the operator, must not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disclose a combination code or personal identification code; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use another person’s combination code or personal identification code.

Subsection.Text: A person to whom a restricted area identity card or a key has been issued must immediately report its loss or theft to their employer or to the operator of an aerodrome who issued the card or key.

An employer who is informed by an employee of the loss or theft of a restricted area identity card or a key must immediately report the loss or theft to the operator of an aerodrome who issued the card or key.

Section.Text: An employer who is informed by an employee that a restricted area identity card is not functioning must immediately notify the operator of an aerodrome who issued the card.

Heading.TitleText: Presentation and Surrender of Restricted Area Identity Cards

Subsection.Text: A person in possession of a restricted area identity card who is in a restricted area at an aerodrome must, on demand, present the card to the Minister, the operator of the aerodrome, the person’s employer or a peace officer.

A person in possession of a restricted area identity card who is being screened by a screening officer at a restricted area access point or at a location in a restricted area must, on demand, present the card to the screening officer.
A person in possession of a restricted area identity card must, on demand, surrender it to the Minister, the operator of an aerodrome, a screening officer or a peace officer.
The Minister or the operator of an aerodrome may demand the surrender of a restricted area identity card if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the card has expired or has been reported as lost or stolen;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the card has been deactivated; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the surrender of the card is required to ensure aviation security.

Subsection.Text: A screening officer may demand the surrender of a restricted area identity card if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the card has expired or has been reported as lost or stolen;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the card has been deactivated; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the screening officer is carrying out screening at a restricted area access point or at a location in a restricted area and the person who is in possession of the card refuses to be screened or refuses to submit goods in their possession or control for screening.

Subsection.Text: A peace officer may demand the surrender of a restricted area identity card if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the card has expired or has been reported as lost or stolen; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an immediate threat to aviation security, the security of any aircraft or aerodrome or other aviation facility or the safety of the public, passengers or crew members, and the surrender of the card is required to respond to the threat.

Section.Text: A screening officer or a peace officer to whom a person surrenders a restricted area identity card must return the card to the operator of the aerodrome where the card is surrendered or to the operator of an aerodrome who issued the card.
The operator of an aerodrome to whom a person surrenders a restricted area identity card must notify the Minister if the operator demanded the surrender in accordance with paragraph 332(2)(c).

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that any person who is in a restricted area at the aerodrome and is not in possession of a restricted area identity card

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is escorted by a person in possession of an active restricted area identity card that has been issued to them; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
